thread.title: Trump calls for 'constructive' US-China relationship in letter
thread.title_full: Trump calls for 'constructive' US-China relationship in letter - BBC News

author: BBC
title: Trump calls for 'constructive' US-China relationship in letter
text:
Mr Trump has been calling world leaders in recent weeks US President Donald Trump has sent a letter to Xi Jinping, his first direct approach to the Chinese leader.
The president thanked Mr Xi for his "congratulatory letter" on his inauguration, and said he looked forward to "constructive" relations.
Mr Trump has not spoken to Mr Xi, but has called several other world leaders.
The letter, featuring standard diplomatic pleasantries, comes after a steady stream of belligerent attacks aimed at Chinese trade and policies.
In recent months, Mr Trump has challenged Beijing on sensitive issues such as Taiwan and the South China Sea. He angered China by taking a call from Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen, the first involving a US President or President-elect in decades.
China sees Taiwan as a breakaway province to be reunited with the mainland, if force by necessary. The US cut formal ties with Taiwan in 1979.
China's gamble for global supremacy in the Trump era Is Taiwan a bargaining-chip for Trump on China? Chinese Year of the Rooster marked with huge Trump sculpture "President Trump stated that he looks forward to working with President Xi to develop a constructive relationship that benefits both the United States and China," the letter said, according to the White House.
Mr Trump also wished the Chinese people "a happy Lantern Festival and prosperous Year of the Rooster".
The Chinese are currently celebrating the Lunar New Year, and the official celebration period will end on Saturday with the Lantern Festival.
Beijing has yet to respond to his latest letter.
China has been angered by Mr Trump's comments on the One China policy concerning Taiwan The conciliatory tone is in stark contrast to previous statements by Mr Trump, whose presidential campaign was marked by anti-China rhetoric that continued after winning the election.
In December, before his inauguration, Mr Trump posted a series of tweets criticising China for its exchange rate policy and its operations in the South China Sea.
He also questioned the One China policy, which is the diplomatic acknowledgement by the US of Beijing's position that there is only one Chinese government, following his call with Taiwan.
Shortly after he took office on 20 January, his administration vowed to prevent China from taking territory in the South China Sea.
Beijing has so far responded cautiously, expressing "serious concern" about Mr Trump's position on the One China policy, and urging the US to maintain close ties with China.
It also lodged a protest over the phone call with Ms Tsai, dismissing it as a "petty trick", and maintained it would "defend its rights" in the South China Sea.
But state media outlets have been less restrained and have issued strongly-worded rebukes, blasting Mr Trump for "playing with fire" on the Taiwan issue.
They also warned of serious action and a "resolute battle" against Mr Trump.
